page.title: 01Landscape:Drainage & Relief.
page.content: Hadleigh and North-West Leigh-on-Sea lie on a{plateau}60m. above sea-level which slopes gently to the east. This plateau is drained by the {Prittle Brook,}which rises near West Wood and flows eastwards. Once in Leigh it becomes a concrete-lined conduit for much of its course through Southend-on-Sea until it joins the River Roach at Rochford. The brook has cut a shallow valley which gives a slight relief to the otherwise almost flat plateau surface. To the south of Hadleigh, sloping down to the Thames Estuary are the {Hadleigh Downs.}From this degraded cliff-line of the River Thames, there is a sweeping view across the estuary to Kent. Local people, especially dog owners,like to walk along these downs.
